byline.contributor: Dalia Sussman and Marina Stefan contributed reporting.
byline.original: By KEVIN SACK and MEGAN THEE-BRENAN

abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll shows nearly six in 10 Americans views race relations in United States unfavorably, signaling striking change since Pres Obama's election victory in 2008, when two-thirds of Americans described relations as generally good; wide swings in opinion are most pronounced among African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: By comparison, two-thirds of Americans surveyed shortly after President Obama took office said they believed race relations were generally good.

headline.main: Poll Finds Most in U.S. Hold Dim View of Race Relations
headline.print_headline: A Broad Division Over Race in U.S. Is Found in Poll
